question.text: A positive charge <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>q</mi></math> is given to each plate of a parallel plate air capacitor having plate area <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> and plate separation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi></math>, then

options.text: since both the plates are identically charged, therefore, capacitance becomes equal to zero

energy stored in the space between the capacitor plates is equal to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></math>
no charge appears on inner surface of the plates

potential difference between the plates is equal to <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>q</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mi>A</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>

solution.text:
Capacitance does not depend on charge on it, C=ε0Ad



In final charge distribution, Charge on outer plates q1=q4=q and inner plates q2=q3=0

As charge on inner plates are zero so there is no field between the plates and no potential difference and no energy is stored.
